document.title: South Carolina Academic Standards and Performance Indicators for Science

C0D7B07C13D74F09ABC46132CF9C3DBE.description:
Construct scientific arguments to explain how animals can change their environments
(such as the shape of the land or the flow of water).

50A9F3A0C3C2484DA8EC9640E1BFE088.description:
Analyze and interpret data from observations to describe how animals respond to
changes in their environment (such as changes in food availability, water, or air).

EB564D7A28344066ABF11BDD47EED372.description:
Develop and use models to exemplify characteristics of animals that help them survive
in distinct environments (such as salt and freshwater, deserts, forests, wetlands, or polar
lands).

7E3BA389C2A846EAB2B2331D4CFE486F.description:
Obtain and communicate information to describe and compare how animals interact with
other animals and plants in the environment.

E27A75032501438981B706897E508F06.description:
Animals (including humans) require air, water, food, and
shelter to survive in environments where these needs can be met. There are distinct environments in
the world that support different types of animals. Environments can change slowly or quickly.
Animals respond to these changes in different ways.

D9A101C2F7E0471F93BC1641EEF7E58B.description:
Construct explanations using observations and measurements of an animal as it grows
and changes to describe the stages of development of the animal.

53418B0B03AE4163B9F984C7BDC02FCF.description:
Construct explanations for how structures (including structures for seeing, hearing,
grasping, protection, locomotion, and obtaining and using resources) of different animals
help them survive.

0BF9F94DB5D4408792ED86C57E677F93.description:
Obtain and communicate information to classify animals (such as mammals, birds,
amphibians, reptiles, fish, or insects) based on their physical characteristics.

775103BD7A93407B8ABBFAF6D602A41C.description:
There are many different groups of animals. One way to
group animals is by using their physical characteristics. Animals have basic needs that provide for
energy, growth, reproduction, and protection. Animals have predictable characteristics at different
stages of development.

564D12D4319D46FD815A31291E708A39.description: Life Science: Animals and Their Environments

7BDF6024FC414120981C5F59DEF7D6BE.description:
Define problems related to the effects of friction and design possible solutions to reduce
the effects on the motion of an object.

0702DB6157AB44F9A6C7D3559CB6C5AC.description:
Conduct structured investigations to answer questions about the relationship between
friction and the motion of objects.

A49CD724B4C0483BA6B344C0200932D6.description:
Construct explanations of the relationship between the motion of an object and the pull
of gravity using observations and data collected.

BEF37E7AF7D84D14BFE9DAAA0B3905E2.description: Develop and use models to exemplify the effects of pushing and pulling on an object.

8F46327798D94EBA9B6A5344F03981A0.description:
Analyze and interpret data from observations and measurements to compare the effects
of different strengths and directions of pushing and pulling on the motion of an object.

3BC6BCC29A4241618FCB5CC1EFC767E9.description:
An object that is not moving will only move if it is pushed or
pulled. Pushes and pulls can vary in strength and direction and can affect the motion of an object.
Gravity is a pull that makes objects fall to the ground. Friction is produced when two objects come
in contact with each other and can be reduced if needed.

506B140578D54EB49CB4F04F7CE8115F.description: Physical Science: Exploring Pushes and Pulls

622AA1213F5149F29F16DCED134CAE1C.description: Obtain and communicate information to exemplify the uses of magnets in everyday life.

291B8132D9A3424C99CB6DCAA0D5A09B.description:
Analyze and interpret data from observations to compare the effects of magnets on
various materials.

41549FFD718B400F8E2C620F019CE1DB.description:
Conduct structured investigations to answer questions about how the poles of magnets
attract and repel each other.

95BA09FCF6AB47A99818C83B8B381973.description:
Magnets are a specific type of solid that can attract and repel
certain other kinds of materials, including other magnets. There are some materials that are neither
attracted to nor repelled by magnets. Because of their special properties, magnets are used in
various ways.

1A73B5B87C10480E92F3E25147724B9E.description:
Construct scientific arguments using evidence from investigations to support claims that
some changes in solids or liquids are reversible and some are not when heat is added or
removed.

DA0F6F2915044FF083230BB63EA8D34E.description:
Conduct structured investigations to test how adding or removing heat can cause
changes in solids and liquids.

493C60A7479743059DD615670B737571.description:
Develop and use models to exemplify how matter can be mixed together and separated
again based on the properties of the mixture.

FB3515961517465CA20890FAAE38D317.description:
Analyze and interpret data from observations and measurements to describe the
properties used to classify matter as a solid or a liquid.

69B54AA6B82D4DBDAFCEEB27807BDF5D.description:
Solids and liquids are two forms of matter that have distinct
observable properties. Some matter can be mixed together and then separated again. Solids and
liquids can be changed from one form to another when heat is added or removed.

0286B014DCCC4CCB9D816703FCE6F396.description: Physical Science: Properties of Solids and Liquids

C3CC81BD56294F55874C42731E6BCCF6.description:
Obtain and communicate information about severe weather conditions to explain why
certain safety precautions are necessary.

59C999059A724AF8B381AFA6886F51AF.description:
Develop and use models to describe and compare the effects of wind (moving air) on
objects.

4590463572974BEF9FE55E34457ECB67.description: Analyze local weather data to predict daily and seasonal patterns over time.

E27086D248BB4047B20944A7661290BE.description:
Analyze and interpret data from observations and measurements to describe local
weather conditions (including temperature, wind, and forms of precipitation).

35FF2B5589C043D19A46A3DDC9E8194C.description:
Weather is the combination of sunlight, wind, precipitation
(rain, sleet, snow, and hail), and temperature in a particular region at a particular time. Scientists
measure and record these conditions to describe the weather and to identify patterns over time.
Weather scientists (meteorologists) forecast severe weather so that communities can prepare for and
respond to these events.

8CEF76D50D9B4D33A2B034B41A982157.description:
Construct devices or design solutions to solve specific problems or needs: (1) ask
questions to identify problems or needs, (2) ask questions about the criteria and
constraints of the devices or solutions, (3) generate and communicate ideas for possible
devices or solutions, (4) build and test devices or solutions, (5) determine if the devices
or solutions solved the problem, and (6) communicate the results.

C5D1708384A14E64ADBE047A7AFFD155.description:
Technology is any modification to the natural world created
to fulfill the wants and needs of humans. The engineering design process involves a series of
iterative steps used to solve a problem and often leads to the development of a new or improved
technology.

C18CC73DE00741FBA9DAE5A00E4D6720.description:
Obtain and evaluate informational texts, observations, data collected, or discussions to
(1) generate and answer questions about the natural world, (2) understand phenomena,
(3) develop models, or (4) support explanations. Communicate observations and
explanations using oral and written language.

20F79F9BA2E341A0AE5B4C9D44AA56CE.description:
Construct scientific arguments to support claims or explanations using evidence from
observations or data collected.

9CE0934647B54AF8B44FBBFDFDD9A270.description:
Construct explanations of phenomena using (1) student-generated observations and
measurements, (2) results of scientific investigations, or (3) data communicated in
graphs, tables, or diagrams.

04AD6E0707C74637B4034921A01455C0.description:
Use mathematical and computational thinking to (1) express quantitative observations
using appropriate English or metric units, (2) collect and analyze data, or (3) understand
patterns, trends and relationships.

DB3515FE703F44A397116DDF1A08B42D.description:
Analyze and interpret data from observations, measurements, or investigations to
understand patterns and meanings.

5A2F28175797498CA47AAC770BF50BE3.description:
With teacher guidance, conduct structured investigations to answer scientific questions,
test predictions and develop explanations: (1) predict possible outcomes, (2) identify
materials and follow procedures, (3) use appropriate tools or instruments to collect
qualitative and quantitative data, and (4) record and represent data in an appropriate
form. Use appropriate safety procedures.

32E173AD4B6649DFBE99DD1A2E84C7CB.description:
Develop and use models to (1) understand or represent phenomena, processes, and
relationships, (2) test devices or solutions, or (3) communicate ideas to others.

3DD02F155F544278B358201BEC1B8084.description:
Ask and answer questions about the natural world using explorations, observations, or
structured investigations.

14E039B826714EF0ABDC9B2FF8ED79B7.description:
The practices of science and engineering support the
development of science concepts, develop the habits of mind that are necessary for scientific
thinking, and allow students to engage in science in ways that are similar to those used by scientists
and engineers
